messageBody:
Hi J.B.,

I'm sorry to disagree with you, but I don't think what Michael is
doing is completely wrong. I understand that the framework offers us
a lot of possibilities, and it's up to us to choose what's the best
way to use it, according to our needs and purposes. I think all
approaches have its pros and cons; for example, the approach he's
using, of running batch tests starting with "Test", has the problem
of not selecting a particular set of tests to run each time, but he
has the benefit of not worrying about anything except his unit tests.
The suite approach, as you suggests, has a pro of grouping tests, but
has also a con of hard-coding in a class which tests should be run.
This is related to the problem I have, of running a piece of code
somewhere before all tests.

If I've said something wrong, feel free to correct me, I'm always
ready to learn.

Leonardo Barros

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
>
> >So said Michael Orozco on 2003-07-11 --------------------
> >I am probably doing this all wrong! But If I only want to run
certain
> >tests. I put a letter in front of the test that I don't want to
run, and
> >it is ignored at runtime. I do this because junit usually runs the
methods
> >that have the word test in front of it, and ignores the others.
> >
> >If there is a better, or proper way to do this please let me know.
>
> Yes. Identify the tests that you tend to run as a group, then put
them in a smaller suite.
>
> Either that or build your own TestCollector that creates a suite of
the methods you want. It would be relatively easy to build the
accompanying GUI to make it simpler to pick tests.
>
> Look at GSBase's RecursiveTestSuite, which allows you to filter
tests based on any criterion you can ask the Test object.
>
> Take care.
>
